Architecture Overview

HyperTIES was a sophisticated multi-language system that pioneered many concepts we take for granted in modern hypertext systems. This diagram shows how its components worked together to create the first commercial hypertext browser.

User Interface Layer

HyperTIES supported both mouse and touchscreen input in 1988! User events flowed through an event manager that could handle direct manipulation of hypertext elements.

NeWS Window System

Built on Sun's Network extensible Window System, HyperTIES leveraged PostScript for all display operations. This gave it powerful graphics capabilities and network transparency. The integration with pie menus was handled at this level.

HyperTIES Core

The heart of the system consisted of:

  • Forth Interpreter: Processed .st0 storyboard files containing formatting commands
  • C Formatter: The fmt.c engine handled text layout, font metrics, and page composition
  • C-PS Bridge: fmt.cps provided the communication protocol between C and PostScript
  • Master Index: Managed all documents, pictures, and targets in the system

Data Layer

HyperTIES used a file-based approach with specialized formats:

  • .st0 - Storyboard files containing text and formatting commands
  • .pn0 - Picture files (raster images)
  • .tn0 - Target files (interactive elements)
  • master-index - Central registry of all content

Authoring Tools

Content creation was supported through:

  • Emacs Mode: A MockLisp-based authoring environment (ht.ml)
  • XML Converter: Modern Python tool to preserve HyperTIES content

Data Flow

The typical flow for displaying a hypertext page:

  1. User clicks a link or navigates to an article
  2. Forth interpreter loads and parses the .st0 file
  3. Formatting commands are sent to the C formatter
  4. C formatter calculates layout and generates PostScript
  5. PostScript is sent through the C-PS bridge to NeWS
  6. NeWS renders the page and handles user interaction
  7. Interactive targets respond to touch/mouse events

Key Innovations

This architecture enabled several groundbreaking features:

  • Separation of content (.st0) from presentation (PostScript)
  • Efficient font metrics caching in the C layer
  • Network-transparent display through NeWS
  • Direct manipulation through targets and pie menus
  • Touchscreen support years before it became common

Technical Concepts Illustrated: This diagram showcases concepts such as multi-language interoperability (Forth, C, PostScript), separation of content and presentation, and early forms of markup languages and user interface management systems.
